scenes.location: Dorian’s private room (near a glass screen)
scenes.summary: Dorian, while smoking a cigarette and studying his reflection, issues secret orders to his impassive servant—first to summon the house-keeper and then to contact the frame-maker to send two men—while he remains guarded and suspicious.

Mrs. Leaf enters in her black silk dress and, after some chattering about the dusty, long-sealed old schoolroom and memories of Dorian’s grandfather, reluctantly hands over the key to the neglected schoolroom at Dorian's request.

scenes.location: Private room within the house, behind a screen
scenes.summary: Alone, Dorian admires a vivid purple satin coverlet and reflects on the cursed portrait lurking behind it. He ruminates on his inner corruption and laments that he once might have had help from Basil, downplaying past reproaches and acknowledging the inevitable decay haunting his soul.

A knock at the door interrupts his brooding. Dorian quickly scribbles a note to Lord Henry and instructs his servant to admit the men waiting outside, all while harboring a deep mistrust of the servant’s observant eyes.

scenes.location: Hallway and along the staircase leading to a secluded room
scenes.summary: Mr. Hubbard, the frame-maker, and his young assistant arrive to help move the covered portrait. As they carefully unhook and transport the picture up the wide front staircase, Dorian assists them intermittently while maintaining strict secrecy over its true nature and destination.

Upon reaching the secret room—filled with childhood relics such as an Italian cassone and a familiar book-case—Dorian reflects bitterly on his past and his isolation. He deliberately conceals the portrait beneath the cover, believing that his secret must remain hidden from prying eyes.

Returning to the library after securing the portrait, Dorian finds tea set out on a decorated table with a note from Lord Henry, a newspaper, and a mysterious yellow book. Disturbed by a red-pencil-marked article about Sibyl Vane’s inquest, he grows uneasy about potential prying by Victor, and becomes absorbed as he begins to read the poisonous, enigmatic book.

After hours lost in reverie over the strange book, Dorian finally dresses for dinner and arrives at the club nearly nine o’clock. There, he meets Lord Henry—who had anticipated his visit—and apologizes for his delay, attributing it to his engrossing reading, as they transition into the dining-room together.
